prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'helping others'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing helping others:
Philippians 2:4: Each of you should look not only to your own interests, but also to the interests of others. 
Hebrews 13:16: And do not neglect to do good and to share with others, for with such sacrifices God is pleased. 
Galatians 6:2: Carry one another’s burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the law of Christ. 
Proverbs 19:17: Kindness to the poor is a loan to the LORD, and He will repay the lender. 
Luke 6:38: Give, and it will be given to you. A good measure, pressed down, shaken together, and running over will be poured into your lap. For with the measure you use, it will be measured back to you.” 
Acts 20:35: In everything, I showed you that by this kind of hard work we must help the weak, remembering the words of the Lord Jesus Himself: ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’” 
1 John 3:17: If anyone with earthly possessions sees his brother in need, but withholds his compassion from him, how can the love of God abide in him? 
Proverbs 22:9: A generous man will be blessed, for he shares his bread with the poor. 
Matthew 5:16: In the same way, let your light shine before men, that they may see your good deeds and glorify your Father in heaven. 
Matthew 5:42: Give to the one who asks you, and do not turn away from the one who wants to borrow from you. 
Other passages: James 2:14-2:17
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of selflessness, generosity, and compassion in the Christian life. They teach that helping others is a reflection of God's love and a fundamental expression of faith, encouraging believers to share their resources, bear each other's burdens, and act with kindness and empathy. By doing so, Christians not only fulfill the law of Christ but also receive blessings in return, as giving is more blessed than receiving.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'immigration'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing immigration:
Leviticus 19:33-19:34: When a foreigner resides with you in your land, you must not oppress him. You must treat the foreigner living among you as native-born and love him as yourself, for you were foreigners in the land of Egypt. I am the LORD your God. 
Exodus 22:21: You must not exploit or oppress a foreign resident, for you yourselves were foreigners in the land of Egypt. 
Exodus 23:9: Do not oppress a foreign resident, since you yourselves know how it feels to be foreigners; for you were foreigners in the land of Egypt. 
Matthew 25:35: For I was hungry and you gave Me something to eat, I was thirsty and you gave Me something to drink, I was a stranger and you took Me in, 
Deuteronomy 27:19: ‘Cursed is he who withholds justice from the foreigner, the fatherless, or the widow.’ And let all the people say, ‘Amen!’ 
Malachi 3:5: “Then I will draw near to you for judgment. And I will be a swift witness against sorcerers and adulterers and perjurers, against oppressors of the widowed and fatherless, and against those who defraud laborers of their wages and deny justice to the foreigner but do not fear Me,” says the LORD of Hosts. 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of treating immigrants with compassion, justice, and kindness. They remind believers to remember their own histories and experiences as strangers and to extend hospitality and protection to those who are foreign or marginalized. The teachings call for empathy and fairness, reflecting God's love and justice for all people.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'eating pork'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing eating pork:
Leviticus 11:7-11:8: And the pig, though it has a split hoof completely divided, does not chew the cud; it is unclean for you. You must not eat their meat or touch their carcasses; they are unclean for you. 
Isaiah 66:17: “Those who consecrate and purify themselves to enter the groves—to follow one in the center of those who eat the flesh of swine and vermin and rats—will perish together,” declares the LORD. 
Deuteronomy 14:8: as well as the pig; though it has a divided hoof, it does not chew the cud. It is unclean for you. You must not eat its meat or touch its carcass. 
Leviticus 11:7: And the pig, though it has a split hoof completely divided, does not chew the cud; it is unclean for you. 
Other passages: Leviticus 11:1-11:47, Romans 14:1-14:23
The verses from Leviticus (11:1-47, 11:7-8) and Deuteronomy (14:8) reflect the Old Testament dietary laws given to the Israelites, which prohibit the consumption of pork as it is considered unclean. Isaiah 66:17 warns against eating unclean foods as part of a broader condemnation of idolatrous practices. In contrast, Romans 14:1-23, from the New Testament, emphasizes the principle of Christian liberty and encourages believers not to judge one another over dietary choices, suggesting that what one eats is a matter of personal conviction and faith.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'sodomy'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing sodomy:
Leviticus 18:22: You must not lie with a man as with a woman; that is an abomination. 
Jude 1:7: In like manner, Sodom and Gomorrah and the cities around them, who indulged in sexual immorality and pursued strange flesh, are on display as an example of those who sustain the punishment of eternal fire. 
Leviticus 20:13: If a man lies with a man as with a woman, they have both committed an abomination. They must surely be put to death; their blood is upon them. 
Leviticus 18:22 and Leviticus 20:13 are verses from the Old Testament that address same-sex relations between men. Leviticus 18:22 describes such acts as detestable, while Leviticus 20:13 prescribes severe consequences for engaging in them. These verses reflect the cultural and religious norms of ancient Israel regarding sexual behavior.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'being born again'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing being born again:
John 3:3: Jesus replied, “Truly, truly, I tell you, no one can see the kingdom of God unless he is born again.” 
1 Peter 1:23: For you have been born again, not of perishable seed, but of imperishable, through the living and enduring word of God. 
2 Corinthians 5:17: Therefore if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation. The old has passed away. Behold, the new has come! 
In John 3:3, Jesus emphasizes the necessity of being "born again" to see the kingdom of God, highlighting a spiritual rebirth that transcends physical existence. In 2 Corinthians 5:17, Paul explains that being in Christ makes a person a new creation, where the old life has passed away and a new life has begun, underscoring the transformative power of faith and the renewal it brings. Together, these verses teach that being born again is a profound spiritual transformation that leads to a new identity and life in Christ.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'power of words'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing power of words:
Proverbs 18:21: Life and death are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruit. 
Ephesians 4:29: Let no unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building up the one in need and bringing grace to those who listen. 
Proverbs 12:18: Speaking rashly is like a piercing sword, but the tongue of the wise brings healing. 
Proverbs 18:21 and Proverbs 12:18 both emphasize the significant impact that words can have on our lives and the lives of others. Proverbs 18:21 highlights that words hold the power of life and death, suggesting that what we say can either uplift and heal or harm and destroy. Similarly, Proverbs 12:18 compares reckless words to the thrusts of a sword, while wise words bring healing, underscoring the importance of speaking thoughtfully and with care.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'slavery'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing slavery:
Galatians 3:28: There is neither Jew nor Greek, slave nor free, male nor female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus. 
Galatians 5:1: It is for freedom that Christ has set us free. Stand firm, then, and do not be encumbered once more by a yoke of slavery. 
Colossians 4:1: Masters, supply your slaves with what is right and fair, since you know that you also have a Master in heaven. 
Exodus 21:16: Whoever kidnaps another man must be put to death, whether he sells him or the man is found in his possession. 
Titus 2:9-2:10: Slaves are to submit to their own masters in everything, to be well-pleasing, not argumentative, not stealing from them, but showing all good faith, so that in every respect they will adorn the teaching about God our Savior. 
These verses collectively emphasize the principles of equality, freedom, and ethical treatment within the context of slavery. Galatians 3:28 highlights the spiritual equality of all people in Christ, transcending social divisions like slavery. Galatians 5:1 speaks to the freedom believers have in Christ, encouraging them to live free from bondage. Colossians 4:1 instructs masters to treat their slaves justly and fairly, recognizing their accountability to God. Titus 2:9-10 advises slaves to be obedient and respectful, so their behavior reflects well on the teachings of Christianity. Together, these passages advocate for a transformation of societal norms through the lens of Christian values.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'gossip'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing gossip:
Proverbs 16:28: A perverse man spreads dissension, and a gossip divides close friends. 
Proverbs 20:19: He who reveals secrets is a constant gossip; avoid the one who babbles with his lips. 
Proverbs 11:13: A gossip reveals a secret, but a trustworthy person keeps a confidence. 
Ephesians 4:29: Let no unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building up the one in need and bringing grace to those who listen. 
Proverbs 26:20: Without wood, a fire goes out; without gossip, a conflict ceases. 
Leviticus 19:16: You must not go about spreading slander among your people. You must not endanger the life of your neighbor. I am the LORD. 
Proverbs 18:8: The words of a gossip are like choice morsels that go down into the inmost being. 
Psalms 34:13: Keep your tongue from evil and your lips from deceitful speech. 
Proverbs 10:18: The one who conceals hatred has lying lips, and whoever spreads slander is a fool. 
These verses collectively emphasize the destructive nature of gossip, highlighting how it can sow discord, betray trust, and harm relationships. They encourage believers to speak with integrity and kindness, avoiding harmful talk that tears others down. Instead, they urge the cultivation of speech that builds up and fosters community, reflecting love and truth.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'the moon'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing the moon:
Psalms 8:3: When I behold Your heavens, the work of Your fingers, the moon and the stars, which You have set in place— 
Psalms 89:37: like the moon, established forever, a faithful witness in the sky.” Selah 
Psalm 8:3 and Psalm 89:37 both highlight the moon as a testament to God's creation and faithfulness. Psalm 8:3 reflects on the majesty of God's handiwork, acknowledging the moon as part of the vast and awe-inspiring universe He has made. Psalm 89:37 uses the moon as a symbol of God's enduring covenant, emphasizing its reliability and permanence as a witness to His steadfast promises.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'lust'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing lust:
Matthew 5:28: But I tell you that anyone who looks at a woman to lust after her has already committed adultery with her in his heart. 
1 John 2:16: For all that is in the world—the desires of the flesh, the desires of the eyes, and the pride of life—is not from the Father but from the world. 
Galatians 5:16: So I say, walk by the Spirit, and you will not gratify the desires of the flesh. 
Colossians 3:5: Put to death, therefore, the components of your earthly nature: sexual immorality, impurity, lust, evil desires, and greed, which is idolatry. 
2 Timothy 2:22: Flee from youthful passions and pursue righteousness, faith, love, and peace, together with those who call on the Lord out of a pure heart. 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of guarding one's heart and mind against lustful desires. Matthew 5:28 highlights that lustful thoughts are akin to committing adultery in one's heart, underscoring the seriousness of internal purity. The other verses, such as 1 John 2:16, Galatians 5:16, and 2 Timothy 2:22, encourage believers to live by the Spirit, flee youthful passions, and pursue righteousness, suggesting that overcoming lust involves a conscious effort to align one's life with spiritual values and virtues.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'forgiveness of sins'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing forgiveness of sins:
1 John 1:9: If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness. 
Colossians 3:13: Bear with one another and forgive any complaint you may have against someone else. Forgive as the Lord forgave you. 
Mark 11:25: And when you stand to pray, if you hold anything against another, forgive it, so that your Father in heaven will forgive your trespasses as well.” 
Acts 2:38: Peter replied, “Repent and be baptized, every one of you, in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit. 
Ephesians 1:7: In Him we have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses, according to the riches of His grace 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance and availability of forgiveness through faith and practice. 1 John 1:9 assures us that if we confess our sins, God is faithful and just to forgive us and cleanse us from all unrighteousness. Colossians 3:13 and Mark 11:25 highlight the necessity of forgiving others as the Lord forgave us, underscoring forgiveness as a reciprocal and essential part of Christian life. Ephesians 1:7 reminds us that through Christ's sacrifice, we have redemption and forgiveness of sins, demonstrating the grace and richness of God's mercy.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'church leadership'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing church leadership:
Hebrews 13:17: Obey your leaders and submit to them, for they watch over your souls as those who must give an account. To this end, allow them to lead with joy and not with grief, for that would be of no advantage to you.

Together, these verses highlight the responsibility and accountability of church leaders to guide and nurture their congregations with diligence and integrity.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'hope'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing hope:
Romans 15:13: Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace as you believe in Him, so that you may overflow with hope by the power of the Holy Spirit. 
Jeremiah 29:11: For I know the plans I have for you, declares the LORD, plans to prosper you and not to harm you, to give you a future and a hope. 
Isaiah 40:31: But those who wait upon the LORD will renew their strength; they will mount up with wings like eagles; they will run and not grow weary, they will walk and not faint. 
Hebrews 11:1: Now faith is the assurance of what we hope for and the certainty of what we do not see. 
Romans 12:12: Be joyful in hope, patient in affliction, persistent in prayer.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'dreams and visions'?
completion:

Joel 2:28: And afterward, I will pour out My Spirit on all people. Your sons and daughters will prophesy, your old men will dream dreams, your young men will see visions.

Numbers 12:6: He said, “Hear now My words: If there is a prophet among you, I, the LORD, will reveal Myself to him in a vision; I will speak to him in a dream.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'judging other christians'?
completion:

Matthew 7:1: “Do not judge, or you will be judged. 
John 7:24: Stop judging by outward appearances, and start judging justly.”

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'cosigning a loan'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing cosigning a loan:
Proverbs 17:18: A man lacking judgment strikes hands in pledge and puts up security for his neighbor. 
Proverbs 11:15: He who puts up security for a stranger will surely suffer, but the one who hates indebtedness is secure. 
Proverbs 22:26-22:27: Do not be one who gives pledges, who puts up security for debts. If you have nothing with which to pay, why should your bed be taken from under you? 
Proverbs 22:7: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is slave to the lender. 
Psalms 37:21: The wicked borrow and do not repay, but the righteous are gracious and giving. 
Other passages: Proverbs 6:1-6:5
These verses collectively caution against the practice of cosigning a loan, highlighting the potential financial risk and burden it can impose. Proverbs 17:18 and 11:15 warn that cosigning can lead to trouble and regret, while Proverbs 22:26-27 advises against pledging security for others' debts, as it may result in losing one's own resources. Additionally, Proverbs 22:7 and Psalm 37:21 emphasize the power dynamics of debt, where the borrower becomes a servant to the lender, and the importance of fulfilling financial obligations.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'humility'?
completion:

Proverbs 22:4: The rewards of humility and the fear of the LORD are wealth and honor and life. 
Proverbs 11:2: When pride comes, disgrace follows, but with humility comes wisdom. 
James 4:10: Humble yourselves before the Lord, and He will exalt you. 
Colossians 3:12: Therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, clothe yourselves with hearts of compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience. 
Micah 6:8: He has shown you, O man, what is good. And what does the LORD require of you but to act justly, to love mercy, and to walk humbly with your God? 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of humility as a virtue that aligns with God's will and brings blessings. Proverbs 22:4 highlights that humility, coupled with the fear of the Lord, leads to riches, honor, and life. Proverbs 11:2 warns that pride leads to disgrace, while humility brings wisdom. prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'man as head of household'?
completion:

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'healing the sick'?

Together, these verses teach that healing is closely linked to faith, obedience, and the support of the faith community.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'business'?
completion:

Deuteronomy 8:18: But remember that it is the LORD your God who gives you the power to gain wealth, in order to confirm His covenant that He swore to your fathers even to this day. 
Deuteronomy 8:18 emphasizes that it is God who gives individuals the ability to produce wealth, reminding us that our talents and opportunities in business are gifts from Him. This verse encourages humility and gratitude, urging us to remember the Lord's role in our success and to use our resources in ways that honor Him and uphold His covenant.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'homelessness'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing homelessness:
Proverbs 19:17: Kindness to the poor is a loan to the LORD, and He will repay the lender. 
Matthew 8:20: Jesus replied, “Foxes have dens and birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man has no place to lay His head.” 
Proverbs 19:17 emphasizes the virtue of kindness and generosity towards the poor, suggesting that helping those in need is akin to lending to the Lord, who will repay such acts of compassion. Matthew 8:20 highlights the humility and lack of worldly possessions in Jesus' own life, illustrating that even the Son of Man had no permanent home, thereby encouraging empathy and solidarity with those experiencing homelessness. Together, these verses call for compassion, generosity, and understanding towards the homeless.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'choosing friends'?

Proverbs 27:17: As iron sharpens iron, so one man sharpens another. 
Proverbs 17:17: A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity. 
Proverbs 12:26: A righteous man is cautious in friendship, but the ways of the wicked lead them astray. 
Proverbs 22:24-22:25: Do not make friends with an angry man, and do not associate with a hot-tempered man, or you may learn his ways and entangle yourself in a snare.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'being taken advantage of'?
completion:

Matthew 10:16: Behold, I am sending you out like sheep among wolves; therefore be as shrewd as snakes and as innocent as doves.

Meanwhile, 1 Thessalonians 4:6 warns against wronging or taking advantage of others, emphasizing that the Lord is an avenger in such matters, and highlighting the importance of treating others with fairness and integrity. Together, these verses teach us to seek God's guidance to avoid being exploited and to act justly towards others.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'marrying a divorced woman'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing marrying a divorced woman:
Matthew 5:32: But I tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, brings adultery upon her. And he who marries a divorced woman commits adultery. 
Matthew 19:9: Now I tell you that whoever divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, and marries another woman commits adultery.” 
Luke 16:18: Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery, and he who marries a divorced woman commits adultery. 
Malachi 2:16: “For I hate divorce,” says the LORD, the God of Israel. “He who divorces his wife covers his garment with violence,” says the LORD of Hosts. So guard yourselves in your spirit and do not break faith. 
1 Corinthians 7:39: A wife is bound to her husband as long as he lives. But if her husband dies, she is free to marry anyone she wishes, as long as he belongs to the Lord. 
Matthew 5:31-5:32: It has also been said, ‘Whoever divorces his wife must give her a certificate of divorce.’ But I tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, brings adultery upon her. And he who marries a divorced woman commits adultery.

These verses collectively emphasize the sanctity and permanence of marriage, highlighting that divorce and remarriage can lead to adultery, except in cases of sexual immorality. They underscore God's original design for marriage as a lifelong union between a man and a woman, as seen in Genesis 2:24, and encourage faithfulness and commitment within the marital relationship. Additionally, 1 Corinthians 7:39 suggests that a widow is free to remarry, but it should be "in the Lord," indicating the importance of shared faith in marriage.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'entering the kingdom of god'?

Jesus explains to Nicodemus that one must be "born of water and the Spirit" to see and enter God's kingdom, highlighting the importance of both baptism and the transformative work of the Holy Spirit in a believer's life. This passage underscores the idea that entry into the kingdom is not based on physical birth or human effort, but on a spiritual renewal and divine intervention.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'courage'?

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'obeying authority'?

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'water'?
completion:

Unlike physical water that temporarily quenches thirst, the living water that Jesus provides leads to everlasting satisfaction and a deep, abiding relationship with God. This verse highlights the transformative and sustaining power of faith in Christ.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'peace of mind'?

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'disabled people'?

These verses collectively emphasize the inherent value and dignity of disabled individuals, highlighting God's sovereignty and purpose in creation. In 2 Corinthians 12:9, Paul speaks of God's grace being sufficient and His power being made perfect in weakness, and Romans 5:3-5 encourages perseverance and hope through suffering, suggesting that challenges can lead to spiritual growth and character development.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'adversity'?

Romans 8:28 assures believers that God works all things, including challenges, for their good. James 1:2-4 encourages embracing trials as opportunities for developing perseverance and maturity, while 2 Corinthians 4:8-9 highlights resilience through God's sustaining power. Proverbs 24:10 warns against faltering in difficult times, and Romans 12:2 calls for transformation through the renewal of the mind, enabling believers to discern and align with God's will even amidst adversity.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'end-time people'?
completion:

1 Timothy 4:1: Now the Spirit expressly states that in later times some will abandon the faith to follow deceitful spirits and the teachings of demons,

They will display a form of godliness but deny its power, engaging in actions that are contrary to true faith. Similarly, 1 Timothy 4:1 cautions that some will abandon the faith, following deceiving spirits and teachings that lead them away from the truth. prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'employees'?

These verses collectively emphasize the importance of nurturing and guiding children in a loving and godly manner. Proverbs 22:6 highlights the significance of training children in the right path so they remain steadfast in their faith as they grow. Ephesians 6:4 advises parents to raise their children with discipline and instruction from the Lord, while Proverbs 17:6 and Psalm 127:3 celebrate children as a source of joy and a blessing from God.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'being a good steward'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing being a good steward:
1 Corinthians 4:2: Now it is required of stewards that they be found faithful. 
Colossians 3:23: Whatever you do, work at it with your whole being, as for the Lord and not for men, 
1 Peter 4:10: As good stewards of the manifold grace of God, each of you should use whatever gift he has received to serve one another. 
1 Timothy 5:8: If anyone does not provide for his own, and especially his own household, he has denied the faith and is worse than an unbeliever. 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of faithfulness, diligence, and responsibility in stewardship. 1 Corinthians 4:2 highlights the necessity of being trustworthy in managing what has been entrusted to us. Colossians 3:23 encourages us to work wholeheartedly as if serving the Lord, while 1 Timothy 5:8 underscores the duty to provide for one's family, indicating that stewardship extends to caring for those under our care. Together, they teach that being a good steward involves integrity, dedication, and a commitment to fulfilling our responsibilities.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'dragon'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing dragon:
Isaiah 27:1: In that day the LORD will take His sharp, great, and mighty sword, and bring judgment on Leviathan the fleeing serpent —Leviathan the coiling serpent—and He will slay the dragon of the sea. 
Revelation 12:9: And the great dragon was hurled down—that ancient serpent called the devil and Satan, the deceiver of the whole world. He was hurled to the earth, and his angels with him. 
Revelation 12:3: Then another sign appeared in heaven: a huge red dragon with seven heads, ten horns, and seven royal crowns on his heads. 
Ezekiel 29:3: Speak to him and tell him that this is what the Lord GOD says: Behold, I am against you, O Pharaoh king of Egypt, O great monster who lies among his rivers, who says, ‘The Nile is mine; I made it myself.’ 
In the Bible, dragons are often symbolic representations of chaos, evil, or oppressive powers. Isaiah 27:1 speaks of the Lord's victory over the leviathan, a dragon-like creature, symbolizing God's ultimate triumph over evil. Revelation 12:9 identifies the dragon as Satan, the deceiver of the world, while Ezekiel 29:3 uses the imagery of a dragon to describe Pharaoh, representing the oppressive and prideful nature of earthly powers that stand against God. Together, these verses emphasize God's sovereignty and power over all forms of evil and opposition.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'eating disorders'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing eating disorders:
1 Corinthians 6:19-6:20: Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit who is in you, whom you have received from God? You are not your own; you were bought at a price. Therefore glorify God with your body. 
1 Samuel 16:7: But the LORD said to Samuel, “Do not consider his appearance or height, for I have rejected him; the LORD does not see as man does. For man sees the outward appearance, but the LORD sees the heart.” 
Romans 12:1: Therefore I urge you, brothers, on account of God’s mercy, to offer your bodies as living sacrifices, holy and pleasing to God, which is your spiritual service of worship. 
1 Corinthians 10:13: No temptation has seized you except what is common to man. And God is faithful; He will not let you be tempted beyond what you can bear. But when you are tempted, He will also provide an escape, so that you can stand up under it. 
Psalms 139:14: I praise You, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made. Marvelous are Your works, and I know this very well. 
Song of Songs 4:7: You are altogether beautiful, my darling; in you there is no flaw. 
Matthew 6:25: Therefore I tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or drink; or about your body, what you will wear. Is not life more than food, and the body more than clothes? 
James 4:7: Submit yourselves, then, to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you. 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of viewing our bodies as temples of the Holy Spirit, deserving of care and respect (1 Corinthians 6:19-20). They remind us that God values our inner beauty and heart over outward appearances (1 Samuel 16:7) and encourage us to present our bodies as living sacrifices, honoring God through our actions (Romans 12:1). Additionally, they offer reassurance of God's faithfulness in providing strength and a way out of temptation (1 Corinthians 10:13), affirm our inherent worth and beauty as God's creation (Psalm 139:14, Song of Solomon 4:7), and call us to submit to God, resisting harmful influences (James 4:7).

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'arguing'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing arguing:
Proverbs 15:1: A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger. 
2 Timothy 2:23-2:24: But reject foolish and ignorant speculation, for you know that it breeds quarreling. And a servant of the Lord must not be quarrelsome, but must be kind to everyone, able to teach, and forbearing. 
Philippians 2:14: Do everything without complaining or arguing, 
Romans 14:19: So then, let us pursue what leads to peace and to mutual edification. 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of maintaining peace and avoiding unnecessary disputes. Proverbs 15:1 highlights the power of a gentle response to defuse anger, while 2 Timothy 2:23-24 advises against engaging in foolish arguments, encouraging a demeanor of kindness and patience. Romans 14:19 calls believers to pursue actions that lead to peace and mutual edification, underscoring the value of building each other up rather than engaging in conflict.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'reputation'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing reputation:
Proverbs 22:1: A good name is more desirable than great riches; favor is better than silver and gold. 
Ecclesiastes 7:1: A good name is better than fine perfume, and one’s day of death is better than his day of birth. 
Philippians 2:7: but emptied Himself, taking the form of a servant, being made in human likeness. 
Proverbs 22:1 emphasizes the value of a good reputation, stating that it is more desirable than great wealth, highlighting the importance of integrity and character over material possessions. Philippians 2:7, on the other hand, illustrates how Jesus humbled Himself by taking on the nature of a servant, teaching us that true greatness and a lasting reputation come from humility and selflessness rather than seeking status or recognition. Together, these verses encourage us to prioritize character and humility in building a meaningful and respected reputation.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'thieves'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing thieves:
Ephesians 4:28: He who has been stealing must steal no longer, but must work, doing good with his own hands, that he may have something to share with the one in need. 
Ephesians 4:28 teaches that those who have been stealing should stop and instead work honestly to earn their living. The verse emphasizes the importance of transformation and encourages individuals to contribute positively to the community by sharing with those in need. This reflects a broader Christian principle of repentance, renewal, and generosity.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'charging interest'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing charging interest:
Exodus 22:25: If you lend money to one of My people among you who is poor, you must not act as a creditor to him; you are not to charge him interest. 
Deuteronomy 23:19: Do not charge your brother interest on money, food, or any other type of loan. 
Psalms 15:5: who lends his money without interest and refuses a bribe against the innocent. He who does these things will never be shaken. 
Deuteronomy 23:19-23:20: Do not charge your brother interest on money, food, or any other type of loan. You may charge a foreigner interest, but not your brother, so that the LORD your God may bless you in everything to which you put your hand in the land that you are entering to possess. 
Proverbs 28:8: He who increases his wealth by interest and usury lays it up for one who is kind to the poor. 
Leviticus 25:35-25:37: Now if your countryman becomes destitute and cannot support himself among you, then you are to help him as you would a foreigner or stranger, so that he can continue to live among you. Do not take any interest or profit from him, but fear your God, that your countryman may live among you. You must not lend him your silver at interest or sell him your food for profit. 
Matthew 25:27: Then you should have deposited my money with the bankers, and on my return I would have received it back with interest. 
Proverbs 22:7: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is slave to the lender. 
Ezekiel 22:12: In you they take bribes to shed blood. You engage in usury, take excess interest, and extort your neighbors. But Me you have forgotten, declares the Lord GOD. 
Deuteronomy 23:20: You may charge a foreigner interest, but not your brother, so that the LORD your God may bless you in everything to which you put your hand in the land that you are entering to possess. 
Luke 6:34-6:35: And if you lend to those from whom you expect repayment, what credit is that to you? Even sinners lend to sinners, expecting to be repaid in full. But love your enemies, do good to them, and lend to them, expecting nothing in return. Then your reward will be great, and you will be sons of the Most High; for He is kind to the ungrateful and wicked. 
Matthew 5:42: Give to the one who asks you, and do not turn away from the one who wants to borrow from you. 
Romans 13:8: Be indebted to no one, except to one another in love. For he who loves his neighbor has fulfilled the law. 
The verses collectively emphasize a cautionary stance on charging interest, particularly within the community of believers. They advocate for compassion and generosity, urging individuals to lend without expecting financial gain, especially to those in need. The overarching message is to prioritize relationships and moral integrity over financial profit, reflecting God's call for justice and mercy.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'meditation'?
completion:

Psalms 119:15: I will meditate on Your precepts and regard Your ways. 
Joshua 1:8: This Book of the Law must not depart from your mouth; meditate on it day and night, so that you may be careful to do everything written in it. For then you will prosper and succeed in all you do. 
Psalms 104:34: May my meditation be pleasing to Him, for I rejoice in the LORD. 
Philippians 4:8: Finally, brothers, whatever is true, whatever is honorable, whatever is right, whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is admirable—if anything is excellent or praiseworthy—think on these things. 
Psalms 119:97: Oh, how I love Your law! All day long it is my meditation. 
Psalms 63:6: When I remember You on my bed, I think of You through the watches of the night. 
Psalms 49:3: My mouth will impart wisdom, and the meditation of my heart will bring understanding. 
Psalms 143:5: I remember the days of old; I meditate on all Your works; I consider the work of Your hands. 
Psalms 1:2: But his delight is in the Law of the LORD, and on His law he meditates day and night. 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of meditating on God's word and His works as a means of aligning one's heart and mind with His will. They encourage believers to focus on what is true, noble, and praiseworthy, allowing God's teachings to guide their thoughts and actions. Meditation, in this context, is portrayed as a practice that brings wisdom, understanding, and delight in the Lord's presence.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'thanksgiving'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing thanksgiving:
1 Thessalonians 5:18: Give thanks in every circumstance, for this is God’s will for you in Christ Jesus. 
Psalms 107:1: Give thanks to the LORD, for He is good; His loving devotion endures forever. 
Colossians 3:15: Let the peace of Christ rule in your hearts, for to this you were called as members of one body. And be thankful. 
Colossians 4:2: Devote yourselves to prayer, being watchful and thankful, 
Psalms 50:14: Sacrifice a thank offering to God, and fulfill your vows to the Most High. 
Psalms 100:4: Enter His gates with thanksgiving and His courts with praise; give thanks to Him and bless His name. 
Philippians 4:6: Be anxious for nothing, but in everything, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God.

1 Chronicles 16:34: Give thanks to the LORD, for He is good; His loving devotion endures forever. 
Other passages: Psalms 100:1-100:5
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of cultivating a heart of gratitude towards God, regardless of circumstances. prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'sharing with others'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing sharing with others:
Hebrews 13:16: And do not neglect to do good and to share with others, for with such sacrifices God is pleased. 
Hebrews 13:16 encourages believers to do good and share with others, emphasizing that such actions are pleasing to God. It highlights the importance of generosity and kindness as expressions of faith, reminding us that sharing with others is a form of worship and service to God.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'laying on of hands'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing laying on of hands:
1 Timothy 4:14: Do not neglect the gift that is in you, which was given you through the prophecy spoken over you at the laying on of the hands of the elders. 
1 Timothy 5:22: Do not be too quick in the laying on of hands and thereby share in the sins of others. Keep yourself pure. 
2 Timothy 1:6: For this reason I remind you to fan into flame the gift of God, which is in you through the laying on of my hands. 
Hebrews 6:2: instruction about baptisms, the laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment. 
Acts 19:6: And when Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them, and they spoke in tongues and prophesied. 
Acts 8:17: Then Peter and John laid their hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit. 
Acts 13:3: And after they had fasted and prayed, they laid their hands on them and sent them off. 
Luke 4:40: At sunset, all who were ill with various diseases were brought to Jesus, and laying His hands on each one, He healed them. 
Acts 9:17: So Ananias went to the house, and when he arrived, he placed his hands on Saul. “Brother Saul,” he said, “the Lord Jesus, who appeared to you on the road as you were coming here, has sent me so that you may see again and be filled with the Holy Spirit.” 
Acts 28:8: The father of Publius was sick in bed, suffering from fever and dysentery. Paul went in to see him, and after praying and placing his hands on him, he healed the man. 
The verses on the laying on of hands highlight its significance in various contexts, such as imparting spiritual gifts, commissioning individuals for ministry, and healing the sick. It underscores the sacredness and responsibility associated with this act within the church.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'fellowship'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing fellowship:
Acts 2:42: They devoted themselves to the apostles’ teaching and to the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and to prayer. 
1 John 1:7: But if we walk in the light as He is in the light, we have fellowship with one another, and the blood of Jesus His Son cleanses us from all sin. 
1 John 1:3: We proclaim to you what we have seen and heard, so that you also may have fellowship with us. And this fellowship of ours is with the Father and with His Son, Jesus Christ. 
Matthew 18:20: For where two or three gather together in My name, there am I with them.” 
1 Corinthians 1:9: God, who has called you into fellowship with His Son Jesus Christ our Lord, is faithful. 
Hebrews 10:25: Let us not neglect meeting together, as some have made a habit, but let us encourage one another, and all the more as you see the Day approaching. 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of fellowship among believers as a vital aspect of the Christian faith. Acts 2:42 highlights the early church's commitment to communal activities such as teaching, breaking bread, and prayer. 1 John 1:3 and 1:7 stress the significance of fellowship in maintaining a relationship with God and each other, while Matthew 18:20 assures believers of Christ's presence when they gather in His name. Hebrews 10:25 encourages believers not to forsake meeting together, underscoring the importance of mutual encouragement and support within the community.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'human rights'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing human rights:
Galatians 3:28: There is neither Jew nor Greek, slave nor free, male nor female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus. 
Genesis 1:26: Then God said, “Let Us make man in Our image, after Our likeness, to rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, over the livestock, and over all the earth itself and every creature that crawls upon it.” 
Proverbs 31:8-31:9: Open your mouth for those with no voice, for the cause of all the dispossessed. Open your mouth, judge righteously, and defend the cause of the poor and needy. 
Micah 6:8: He has shown you, O man, what is good. And what does the LORD require of you but to act justly, to love mercy, and to walk humbly with your God? 
Genesis 1:27: So God created man in His own image; in the image of God He created him; male and female He created them. 
These verses collectively emphasize the inherent dignity and equality of all people as created in the image of God. Galatians 3:28 highlights the unity and equality among individuals regardless of race, status, or gender in Christ. Genesis 1:26-27 underscores the divine image in every person, affirming their intrinsic worth, while Proverbs 31:8-9 calls for advocacy and justice for the voiceless and oppressed, urging us to uphold the rights of all individuals.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'burden'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing burden:
Galatians 6:2: Carry one another’s burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the law of Christ. 
Psalms 55:22: Cast your burden upon the LORD and He will sustain you; He will never let the righteous be shaken. 
Galatians 6:2 encourages believers to "carry each other's burdens," emphasizing the importance of community and mutual support in fulfilling the law of Christ. Psalm 55:22 invites individuals to "cast your burden on the Lord," assuring them that God will sustain and care for them. Together, these verses teach that while we are called to support one another, we can also trust in God's strength and faithfulness to help us through our struggles.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'spending money'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing spending money:
Proverbs 22:7: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is slave to the lender. 
1 Timothy 6:10: For the love of money is the root of all kinds of evil. By craving it, some have wandered away from the faith and pierced themselves with many sorrows. 
Proverbs 22:7 highlights the power dynamics involved in financial transactions, stating that "the borrower is slave to the lender," which serves as a caution against excessive debt and encourages prudent financial management. Meanwhile, 1 Timothy 6:10 warns that "the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil," emphasizing that an unhealthy attachment to wealth can lead to moral and spiritual downfall. Together, these verses teach the importance of responsible financial stewardship and the dangers of prioritizing money over spiritual and ethical values.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'signs and wonders'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing signs and wonders:
2 Corinthians 12:12: The marks of a true apostle—signs, wonders, and miracles—were performed among you with great perseverance. 
John 4:48: Jesus said to him, “Unless you people see signs and wonders, you will never believe.” 
Matthew 24:24: For false Christs and false prophets will appear and perform great signs and wonders to deceive even the elect, if that were possible. 
Acts 2:22: Men of Israel, listen to this message: Jesus of Nazareth was a man certified by God to you by miracles, wonders, and signs, which God did among you through Him, as you yourselves know. 
2 Thessalonians 2:9: The coming of the lawless one will be accompanied by the working of Satan, with every kind of power, sign, and false wonder, 
Acts 14:3: So Paul and Barnabas spent considerable time there, speaking boldly for the Lord, who affirmed the message of His grace by enabling them to perform signs and wonders. 
These verses collectively highlight that signs and wonders serve as divine attestations of God's power and the authenticity of His messengers. They emphasize that while signs can confirm the truth of the Gospel and the authority of Jesus and His apostles, they should not be the sole basis for faith, as genuine belief transcends the need for miraculous proof. Additionally, believers are cautioned against being misled by false signs performed by deceivers.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'being humble'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing being humble:
1 Peter 5:6: Humble yourselves, therefore, under God’s mighty hand, so that in due time He may exalt you. 
James 4:6: But He gives us more grace. This is why it says: “God opposes the proud, but gives grace to the humble.” 
2 Chronicles 7:14: and if My people who are called by My name humble themselves and pray and seek My face and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven, forgive their sin, and heal their land. 
James 4:10: Humble yourselves before the Lord, and He will exalt you. 
Proverbs 11:2: When pride comes, disgrace follows, but with humility comes wisdom. 
Micah 6:8: He has shown you, O man, what is good. And what does the LORD require of you but to act justly, to love mercy, and to walk humbly with your God? 
These verses collectively emphasize the importance of humility in the life of a believer. They teach that God favors the humble, offering them grace and lifting them up in due time. Humility involves submitting to God's will, seeking His guidance, and walking justly and mercifully with others, reflecting a heart aligned with His desires.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'heaven'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing heaven:
John 14:2: In My Father’s house are many rooms. If it were not so, would I have told you that I am going there to prepare a place for you? 
Revelation 21:4: ‘He will wipe away every tear from their eyes,’ and there will be no more death or mourning or crying or pain, for the former things have passed away.” 
John 14:2 speaks of heaven as a place with many rooms, prepared by Jesus for those who believe in Him, emphasizing the promise of a personal and welcoming eternal home. Revelation 21:4 describes heaven as a place where God will wipe away every tear, and there will be no more death, mourning, crying, or pain, highlighting the complete restoration and peace that awaits believers. Together, these verses convey a vision of heaven as a place of comfort, belonging, and eternal joy in the presence of God.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'anxiety'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing anxiety:
Philippians 4:6-4:7: Be anxious for nothing, but in everything, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.

John 14:27: Peace I leave with you; My peace I give to you. I do not give to you as the world gives. Do not let your hearts be troubled; do not be afraid. 
2 Timothy 1:7: For God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of power, love, and self-control. 
Psalms 55:22: Cast your burden upon the LORD and He will sustain you; He will never let the righteous be shaken. 
Philippians 4:6: Be anxious for nothing, but in everything, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. 
1 Peter 5:6-5:7: Humble yourselves, therefore, under God’s mighty hand, so that in due time He may exalt you. Cast all your anxiety on Him, because He cares for you. 
Hebrews 13:6: So we say with confidence: “The Lord is my helper; I will not be afraid. What can man do to me?” 
Joshua 1:9: Have I not commanded you to be strong and courageous? Do not be afraid; do not be discouraged, for the LORD your God is with you wherever you go.”

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'protecting children'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing protecting children:
Matthew 18:10: See that you do not look down on any of these little ones. For I tell you that their angels in heaven always see the face of My Father in heaven. 
Ephesians 6:4: Fathers, do not provoke your children to wrath; instead, bring them up in the discipline and instruction of the Lord. 
Matthew 18:10 emphasizes the importance of valuing and protecting children, warning against looking down on them and highlighting their significance in the eyes of God. Ephesians 6:4 instructs parents, particularly fathers, to nurture their children with care and guidance, avoiding actions that provoke anger, and instead raising them with discipline and instruction rooted in the Lord's teachings. Together, these verses underscore the responsibility to safeguard children's well-being and spiritual growth.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'marriage and family'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing marriage and family:
Genesis 2:24: For this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and they will become one flesh. 
1 Peter 3:7: Husbands, in the same way, treat your wives with consideration as a delicate vessel, and with honor as fellow heirs of the gracious gift of life, so that your prayers will not be hindered. 
Genesis 2:18: The LORD God also said, “It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make for him a suitable helper.” 
Hebrews 13:4: Marriage should be honored by all and the marriage bed kept undefiled, for God will judge the sexually immoral and adulterers. 
Proverbs 18:22: He who finds a wife finds a good thing and obtains favor from the LORD.

These verses collectively emphasize the sanctity and unity of marriage, highlighting it as a divine institution where a man and woman become one flesh (Genesis 2:24). They call for mutual respect, love, and honor between spouses, with husbands urged to be understanding and considerate (1 Peter 3:7, Ephesians 5:33). Additionally, marriage is to be held in honor and kept pure, reflecting its importance and value in the eyes of God (Hebrews 13:4), while also recognizing the companionship and support that spouses provide to one another (Genesis 2:18).

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'sovereignty'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing sovereignty:
Psalms 115:3: Our God is in heaven; He does as He pleases. 
Job 42:2: “I know that You can do all things and that no plan of Yours can be thwarted. 
Proverbs 19:21: Many plans are in a man’s heart, but the purpose of the LORD will prevail. 
Romans 8:28: And we know that God works all things together for the good of those who love Him, who are called according to His purpose. 
These verses collectively emphasize the sovereignty of God, highlighting His supreme authority and control over all things. Psalm 115:3 declares that God does whatever pleases Him, underscoring His ultimate power and freedom. Job 42:2 acknowledges that no purpose of God can be thwarted, affirming His ability to accomplish His will, while Romans 8:28 assures believers that God works all things together for good for those who love Him, demonstrating His sovereign orchestration of events for His divine purposes.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'satan and a third of angels caste out of heaven'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing satan and a third of angels caste out of heaven:
Revelation 12:9: And the great dragon was hurled down—that ancient serpent called the devil and Satan, the deceiver of the whole world. He was hurled to the earth, and his angels with him. 
Revelation 12:4: His tail swept a third of the stars from the sky, hurling them to the earth. And the dragon stood before the woman who was about to give birth, ready to devour her child as soon as she gave birth. 
Luke 10:18: So He told them, “I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven. 
Revelation 12:9 describes a cosmic battle in which Satan, referred to as the "great dragon" and "that ancient serpent," is cast out of heaven along with his angels, symbolizing his defeat and expulsion from God's presence. Luke 10:18 records Jesus' words, where He speaks of seeing Satan fall like lightning from heaven, indicating the swift and decisive nature of Satan's downfall. Together, these verses emphasize the ultimate defeat and judgment of Satan and his followers, highlighting God's sovereignty and the triumph of good over evil.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'suffering'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing suffering:
1 Peter 5:10: And after you have suffered for a little while, the God of all grace, who has called you to His eternal glory in Christ, will Himself restore you, secure you, strengthen you, and establish you. 
Romans 8:18: I consider that our present sufferings are not comparable to the glory that will be revealed in us. 
Romans 5:3-5:5: Not only that, but we also rejoice in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope. And hope does not disappoint us, because God has poured out His love into our hearts through the Holy Spirit, whom He has given us.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'polygamy'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing polygamy:
Exodus 21:10: If he takes another wife, he must not reduce the food, clothing, or marital rights of his first wife. 
Deuteronomy 21:15-21:17: If a man has two wives, one beloved and the other unloved, and both bear him sons, but the unloved wife has the firstborn son, when that man assigns his inheritance to his sons he must not appoint the son of the beloved wife as the firstborn over the son of the unloved wife. Instead, he must acknowledge the firstborn, the son of his unloved wife, by giving him a double portion of all that he has. For that son is the firstfruits of his father’s strength; the right of the firstborn belongs to him.

The verses you mentioned provide insights into the cultural context of polygamy in biblical times. Exodus 21:10 addresses the rights of a first wife if a man takes another wife, emphasizing the importance of providing for her needs. Deuteronomy 21:15-17 discusses inheritance rights, ensuring that the firstborn son receives his due share, regardless of the father's affection for the mother. In 2 Samuel 12:8, God speaks to David through the prophet Nathan, mentioning the wives given to him, which reflects the acceptance of polygamy in that historical context, though it is not explicitly endorsed as an ideal practice.

Meanwhile, Luke 16:18 and Matthew 5:32 emphasize the seriousness of divorce and remarriage, suggesting that marrying someone who is divorced can lead to adultery. Together, these passages highlight the sanctity of marriage and the importance of careful consideration before divorce and remarriage.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'retribution'?

Revelation 5:8 depicts the prayers of the saints as incense held in golden bowls, indicating that these prayers are precious and valued in the heavenly realm.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'is all sin the same'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing is all sin the same:
Romans 6:23: For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord. 
Romans 3:23: for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God, 
James 2:10: Whoever keeps the whole law but stumbles at just one point is guilty of breaking all of it. 
John 19:11: Jesus answered, “You would have no authority over Me if it were not given to you from above. Therefore the one who handed Me over to you is guilty of greater sin.” 
1 John 1:9: If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness. 
These verses collectively highlight the universality and seriousness of sin, emphasizing that all have sinned and fall short of God's glory (Romans 3:23) and that the consequence of sin is death (Romans 6:23). James 2:10 underscores that breaking any part of God's law makes one guilty of breaking all of it, suggesting a fundamental equality in the nature of sin. However, 1 John 1:9 offers hope, teaching that if we confess our sins, God is faithful and just to forgive us and cleanse us from all unrighteousness, indicating that while all sin separates us from God, His grace is available to forgive any sin.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'moving away'?

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'shaving'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing shaving:
Leviticus 21:5: Priests must not make bald spots on their heads, shave off the edges of their beards, or make cuts in their bodies. 
Leviticus 19:27: You must not cut off the hair at the sides of your head or clip off the edges of your beard.

Genesis 41:14: So Pharaoh sent for Joseph, who was quickly brought out of the dungeon. After he had shaved and changed his clothes, he went in before Pharaoh. 
The verses you mentioned provide various perspectives on shaving within different contexts. Leviticus 19:27 and 21:5 address the Israelites, instructing them not to shave the edges of their beards or make cuts in their flesh, which is often interpreted as a prohibition against adopting pagan mourning practices. Ezekiel 44:20, on the other hand, instructs priests to keep their hair well-trimmed, while Isaiah 7:20 uses shaving metaphorically to describe an act of judgment. Genesis 41:14 describes Joseph shaving before appearing before Pharaoh, indicating a cultural practice of grooming for respect and cleanliness. Overall, these verses reflect cultural, religious, and metaphorical uses of shaving in biblical times.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'eating the right foods'?

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'church fellowship'?

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'mixed races'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing mixed races:
Galatians 3:28: There is neither Jew nor Greek, slave nor free, male nor female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus. 
2 Corinthians 6:14: Do not be unequally yoked with unbelievers. For what partnership can righteousness have with wickedness? Or what fellowship does light have with darkness? 
Acts 17:26: From one man He made every nation of men, that they should inhabit the whole earth; and He determined their appointed times and the boundaries of their lands.

However, 2 Corinthians 6:14 and Deuteronomy 7:3 caution against forming partnerships that could lead believers away from their faith, though these are often interpreted in a spiritual rather than racial context. Acts 17:26 underscores the common origin and shared humanity of all people, affirming that God created all nations from one blood.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'the immortal soul'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing the immortal soul:

Genesis 2:7: Then the LORD God formed man from the dust of the ground and breathed the breath of life into his nostrils, and the man became a living being. 
Ezekiel 18:4: Behold, every soul belongs to Me; both father and son are Mine. The soul who sins is the one who will die. 
Romans 6:23: For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord. 
Ecclesiastes 9:5: For the living know that they will die, but the dead know nothing. They have no further reward, because the memory of them is forgotten.

These verses collectively emphasize the concept of the soul's significance and its moral accountability. Matthew 10:28 highlights the distinction between physical death and the eternal consequences of the soul, while Genesis 2:7 describes the soul as a divine breath of life. Ezekiel 18:4 and 18:20 stress individual responsibility for sin, indicating that the soul that sins will face death, and Romans 6:23 contrasts the wages of sin, which is death, with the gift of eternal life through Christ, suggesting the soul's potential for immortality through divine grace.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'the death penalty'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing the death penalty:
Genesis 9:6: Whoever sheds the blood of man, by man his blood will be shed; for in His own image God has made mankind. 
Exodus 21:12: Whoever strikes and kills a man must surely be put to death. 
Exodus 20:13: You shall not murder. 
Romans 6:23: For the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord. 
Genesis 9:6 emphasizes the principle of justice, stating that whoever sheds human blood, by humans shall their blood be shed, highlighting the sanctity of human life made in God's image. Exodus 21:12 reinforces this by prescribing death for those who commit murder, reflecting the seriousness of taking a life. Romans 6:23, while primarily addressing spiritual death as the consequence of sin, underscores the gravity of sin and the ultimate need for redemption through Christ, offering a broader perspective on justice and mercy.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'imputed righteousness'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing imputed righteousness:
2 Corinthians 5:21: God made Him who knew no sin to be sin on our behalf, so that in Him we might become the righteousness of God. 
Philippians 3:9: and be found in Him, not having my own righteousness from the law, but that which is through faith in Christ, the righteousness from God on the basis of faith. 
These verses highlight the concept of imputed righteousness, where believers are seen as righteous before God not because of their own deeds, but through faith in Jesus Christ. In 2 Corinthians 5:21, it is explained that Christ, who was sinless, took on our sins so that we might become the righteousness of God. Similarly, Philippians 3:9 emphasizes that righteousness comes through faith in Christ, not from adhering to the law, underscoring the transformative power of faith in receiving God's righteousness.

Genesis 16:1-16 recounts the story of Sarai and Abram, where Sarai, unable to bear children, gives her maidservant Hagar to Abram as a surrogate. This leads to tension and conflict, highlighting the complexities and emotional challenges of surrogacy. Psalm 127:3, on the other hand, emphasizes that children are a gift from the Lord, suggesting that all children, regardless of the circumstances of their birth, are a blessing. Together, these passages reflect both the difficulties and the inherent value of bringing new life into the world.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'work ethic'?

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'everyone is equal'?

Acts 10:34: Then Peter began to speak: “I now truly understand that God does not show favoritism,

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'abundance'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing abundance:

John 10:10: The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy. I have come that they may have life, and have it in all its fullness.

These verses collectively teach that true abundance comes from a relationship with God and aligning our lives with His will. prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'eating meat'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing eating meat:
Genesis 9:3: Everything that lives and moves will be food for you; just as I gave you the green plants, I now give you all things. 
Other passages: Romans 14:1-14:23, Leviticus 11:1-11:47
In Genesis 9:3, God grants Noah and his descendants permission to eat all living creatures, just as He had previously given them green plants, indicating a broad allowance for consuming meat. In Leviticus 11:1-47, however, specific dietary laws are outlined for the Israelites, distinguishing between clean and unclean animals, and thereby restricting the types of meat they could consume. These passages together reflect a transition from a general permission to eat meat to a more regulated dietary practice for the Israelites, emphasizing holiness and obedience to God's commandments.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'fishing'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing fishing:

Matthew 13:47: Once again, the kingdom of heaven is like a net that was cast into the sea and caught all kinds of fish. 
John 21:3: Simon Peter told them, “I am going fishing.” “We will go with you,” they said. So they went out and got into the boat, but caught nothing that night. 
Genesis 1:28: God blessed them and said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth and subdue it; rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air and every creature that crawls upon the earth.” 
Luke 5:6: When they had done so, they caught such a large number of fish that their nets began to tear. 
These verses use fishing as a metaphor for spiritual truths and discipleship. In Matthew 4:19, Jesus calls His disciples to become "fishers of men," emphasizing the mission of spreading the Gospel. The parable in Matthew 13:47 likens the kingdom of heaven to a net that gathers all kinds of fish, illustrating the inclusive nature of God's call. In John 21:3 and Luke 5:6, miraculous catches of fish demonstrate Jesus' power and provision, reinforcing the idea that success in ministry comes through reliance on Him.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'degrees of sin'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing degrees of sin:
John 19:11: Jesus answered, “You would have no authority over Me if it were not given to you from above. Therefore the one who handed Me over to you is guilty of greater sin.” 
1 John 5:16: If anyone sees his brother committing a sin not leading to death, he should ask God, who will give life to those who commit this kind of sin. There is a sin that leads to death; I am not saying he should ask regarding that sin. 
Hebrews 10:26: If we deliberately go on sinning after we have received the knowledge of the truth, no further sacrifice for sins remains, 
Matthew 5:22: But I tell you that anyone who is angry with his brother will be subject to judgment. Again, anyone who says to his brother, ‘Raca,’ will be subject to the Sanhedrin. But anyone who says, ‘You fool!’ will be subject to the fire of hell. 
These verses suggest that there are varying degrees of sin and consequences associated with them. In John 19:11, Jesus implies that some sins are greater than others, as He speaks of a "greater sin." In 1 John 5:16, the distinction between sins that lead to death and those that do not indicates differing severities. Meanwhile, Matthew 5:22 highlights that even anger and insults can lead to judgment, suggesting that sin is not only about actions but also attitudes, with varying degrees of accountability.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'shrimp'?
completion:

Other passages: Genesis 19:1-19:28, Ezekiel 23:18-23:21
The verses you mentioned, Ezekiel 23:18-23:21, do not actually address the topic of shrimp. Instead, they are part of a passage where the prophet Ezekiel uses allegorical language to describe the unfaithfulness of Jerusalem and Samaria through vivid imagery. The Bible does address dietary laws, including the consumption of shrimp, in Leviticus 11:9-12, where it is stated that Israelites should not eat sea creatures without fins and scales, which would include shrimp.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'ungratefulness'?

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'the rapture'?
completion:

1 Thessalonians 4:17: After that, we who are alive and remain will be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air. And so we will always be with the Lord.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'arianism'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing arianism:
John 1:1: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. 
John 10:30: I and the Father are one.” 
Colossians 1:15: The Son is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn over all creation. 
John 17:5: And now, Father, glorify Me in Your presence with the glory I had with You before the world existed. 
1 Timothy 2:5: For there is one God, and there is one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus, 
John 3:16: For God so loved the world that He gave His one and only Son, that everyone who believes in Him shall not perish but have eternal life. 
Revelation 3:14: To the angel of the church in Laodicea write: These are the words of the Amen, the faithful and true Witness, the Originator of God’s creation. 
Arianism is a theological belief that asserts that Jesus Christ is distinct from and subordinate to God the Father. The verses you mentioned provide a counter-narrative to this belief. John 1:1 and John 10:30 emphasize the divinity and unity of Jesus with God, suggesting equality rather than subordination. Colossians 1:15 refers to Jesus as the "firstborn of all creation," which some interpret as supporting Arianism, but traditionally it is understood as indicating preeminence rather than creation. John 17:5 speaks of the glory Jesus shared with the Father before the world existed, affirming His eternal nature. 1 Timothy 2:5 highlights Jesus as the mediator between God and humanity, emphasizing His unique role. Revelation 3:14 refers to Jesus as the "beginning of God's creation," which can be interpreted in various ways, but traditionally it is seen as affirming His role in creation rather than suggesting He was created. Together, these verses are often used to argue against Arianism by affirming the divinity and eternal nature of Christ.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'sin'?

I warn you, as I did before, that those who practice such things will not inherit the kingdom of God.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'palm reading'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing palm reading:

Leviticus 20:27: A man or a woman who is a medium or spiritist must surely be put to death. They shall be stoned; their blood is upon them.’”

The passage from Matthew (MAT 21:1-21:11) does not directly address palm reading but recounts Jesus' triumphal entry into Jerusalem, highlighting themes of faith and the fulfillment of prophecy, which contrast with seeking knowledge through forbidden practices.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'nose piercings'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing nose piercings:
Ezekiel 16:12: I put a ring in your nose, earrings on your ears, and a beautiful crown upon your head. 
Genesis 24:47: Then I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ She replied, ‘The daughter of Bethuel son of Nahor, whom Milcah bore to him.’ So I put the ring on her nose and the bracelets on her wrists. 
1 Samuel 16:7: But the LORD said to Samuel, “Do not consider his appearance or height, for I have rejected him; the LORD does not see as man does. For man sees the outward appearance, but the LORD sees the heart.” 
Genesis 24:30: As soon as he saw the ring, and the bracelets on his sister’s wrists, and heard Rebekah’s words, “The man said this to me,” he went and found the man standing by the camels near the spring. 
Proverbs 11:22: Like a gold ring in a pig’s snout is a beautiful woman who lacks discretion.

The verses you mentioned provide a variety of perspectives on nose piercings. In Genesis 24:47 and Ezekiel 16:12, nose rings are mentioned as adornments, often associated with beauty and blessing, as seen in the context of Rebekah's betrothal and God's adornment of Jerusalem. However, Isaiah 3:18-23 warns against excessive adornment as a sign of vanity, while Proverbs 11:22 uses a nose ring metaphorically to illustrate the incongruity of outward beauty without inner discretion. Ultimately, 1 Samuel 16:7 reminds us that God values the heart over outward appearances.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'changing'?
completion:

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'coveting'?
completion:
These are some popular verses addressing coveting:
Exodus 20:17: You shall not covet your neighbor’s house. You shall not covet your neighbor’s wife, or his manservant or maidservant, or his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor.” 
Romans 7:7: What then shall we say? Is the law sin? Certainly not! Indeed, I would not have been mindful of sin if not for the law. For I would not have been aware of coveting if the law had not said, “Do not covet.” 
Deuteronomy 5:21: You shall not covet your neighbor’s wife. You shall not covet your neighbor’s house or field, or his manservant or maidservant, or his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor.” 
1 Timothy 6:10: For the love of money is the root of all kinds of evil. By craving it, some have wandered away from the faith and pierced themselves with many sorrows. 
Romans 13:9: The commandments “Do not commit adultery,” “Do not murder,” “Do not steal,” “Do not covet,” and any other commandments, are summed up in this one decree: “Love your neighbor as yourself.” 
These verses collectively teach that coveting, or desiring what belongs to others, is contrary to God's commandments and is considered sinful. Exodus 20:17 and Deuteronomy 5:21 explicitly prohibit coveting a neighbor's possessions, while Romans 7:7 and 13:9 highlight how the law reveals the sinfulness of coveting and underscores the importance of love as the fulfillment of the law. Together, they emphasize the need for contentment and respect for others' belongings.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'vindictiveness'?

These references highlight Javan's role in the broader narrative of nations and their interactions in biblical history.

prompt: What does the Bible say about the topic of 'ww3'?

These are some popular verses addressing talking too much:
Proverbs 10:19: When words are many, sin is unavoidable, but he who restrains his lips is wise. 
Proverbs 17:28: Even a fool is considered wise if he keeps silent, and discerning when he holds his tongue. 
Proverbs 18:2: A fool does not delight in understanding, but only in airing his opinions. 
James 1:19: My beloved brothers, understand this: Everyone should be quick to listen, slow to speak, and slow to anger, 
Proverbs 21:23: He who guards his mouth and tongue keeps his soul from distress. 
Psalms 141:3: Set a guard, O LORD, over my mouth; keep watch at the door of my lips. 
Proverbs 29:20: Do you see a man who speaks in haste? There is more hope for a fool than for him. 
Matthew 12:36: But I tell you that men will give an account on the day of judgment for every careless word they have spoken. 
Proverbs 13:3: He who guards his mouth protects his life, but the one who opens his lips invites his own ruin. 
Ecclesiastes 5:2: Do not be quick to speak, and do not be hasty in your heart to utter a word before God. For God is in heaven and you are on earth. So let your words be few. 
Ecclesiastes 9:17: The calm words of the wise are heeded over the shouts of a ruler among fools. 
Proverbs 14:23: There is profit in all labor, but mere talk leads only to poverty. 
James 3:6: The tongue also is a fire, a world of wickedness among the parts of the body. It pollutes the whole person, sets the course of his life on fire, and is itself set on fire by hell. 
Proverbs 18:21: Life and death are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruit. 
Ecclesiastes 5:7: For as many dreams bring futility, so do many words. Therefore, fear God. 
Other passages: Proverbs 15:1-15:33
These verses collectively emphasize the wisdom of restraint in speech, highlighting that excessive talking can lead to sin, misunderstanding, and trouble. They encourage listening more than speaking, guarding one's words, and being mindful of the impact and consequences of what we say. Ultimately, they remind us that thoughtful and measured speech reflects wisdom and understanding.
